monogr.title: An illustration of this kind of "max-min inference" and a discussion of how it relates to Bayesian inference (based on "sum-product aggregation") can be found in Appendix B in the supplementary material. The normalized likelihood was originally introduced by Shafer (1976), and has been justified axiomatically in the context of statistical inference by Wasserman (1990). Further arguments in favor of using the relative likelihood as the contour function of a (consonant) plausibility function are provided by Denoeux

biblStruct.note: 0). who shows that it can be derived from three basic principles: the likelihood principle, compatibility with Bayes' rule, and the so-called minimal commitment principle. See also (Dubois et al.

monogr.title: ) for a discussion of the normalized likelihood in the context of possibility theory
